newsitem.title: FRANCE: Giat bosses released after job cuts protest.
newsitem.headline: Giat bosses released after job cuts protest.

text.p: Eleven executives of state-owned arms maker GIAT Industries were freed on Tuesday after being taken hostage the previous day at a plant in southwest France by workers protesting job cuts.
"The hostage-taking is over," said a spokeswoman for the state-owned arms maker.

Jean-Louis Naudet, secretary-general of the Federation des Travailleurs, affiliated with the communist-led CGT, said the workers at the Tarbes plant decided to release the executives after taking a vote.
But Naudet told Reuters the workers "would keep up the fight" against Giat's plans to cut 595 jobs out of a total of 1,800 at the Tarbes production site as part of a company-wide restruturing plan.

The company, best known for its Leclerc tanks, is planning to cut a total of 2,569 out of 12,000 jobs as part of its restructuring aimed at focusing on its core business of tanks, armoured vehicles and ammunition.

The move is part of a larger reform of the French defence industry under conservative President Jacques Chirac. Hit by a drop in orders since the end of the Cold War, Giat reported a net loss of 10 billion francs for 1995.
